column4: U.S. companies no longer know rules of game under Trump  Hasbro director says
column5: CASCAIS  Portugal Confusion surrounding the trade policies of U.S. President Donald Trump's administration means U.S. companies no longer know the rules of the game  a board member and former CEO of toymaker Hasbro  told an international conference on Monday.

column4: Investigators search Ukrainian offices of Russia's Yandex
column5: KIEV/MOSCOW Ukraine's State Security Service (SBU) raided the Kiev and Odessa offices of Russia's top search site Yandex on Monday  accusing the company of illegally collecting Ukrainian users' data and sending it to Russian security agencies.

column4: China's Lianhua Supermarket says Alibaba takes 18 pct stake
column5: HONG KONG China's Lianhua Supermarket Holdings Co Ltd  on Monday said shareholder Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co Ltd would sell an 18 percent stake in supermarket chain operator to a unit of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd .

column4: UPDATE 4-Barrick says strike ends at Veladero mine in Argentina
column5: BUENOS AIRES  May 29 A strike by one of the labor unions at Barrick Gold Corp's  Veladero mine in Argentina  the site of three cyanide solution spills in 18 months  has ended  the company said on Monday.

column4: Russia squares up to Boeing  Airbus with maiden jet flight
column5: MOSCOW Russia carried out the maiden flight of its new MS-21 medium-range passenger plane on Sunday  its first post-Soviet foray into production of a mainline commercial aircraft which it hopes will rival those of its Western competitors.

column4: Iraq may consider hedging crude production
column5: LARNACA  May 29 Iraq may look at hedging part of its crude oil production  the head of the OPEC member's oil marketer SOMO said  as a way to protect government revenue against the risk of oil price volatility.

column4: UPDATE 3-Akzo Nobel wins court case against dissident shareholders
column5: AMSTERDAM  May 29 A Dutch court on Monday rejected a request by Akzo Nobel investors for it to take immediate action against the  company over its rejection of a takeover bid by U.S. rival PPG Industries  handing the Dutch company a victory in its efforts to repel the U.S. firm's 25 billion euro ($28 billion) proposed offer.

column4: Australian state asks Rio  BHP for upfront cash
column5: SYDNEY The cash-strapped Western Australian state government will ask Rio Tinto and BHP to pay an upfront multi-billion dollar fee in exchange for cancelling an ongoing levy on their iron ore production.

column4: RBS investor group accepts offer to end lawsuit over 2008 cash call
column5: LONDON A group representing Royal Bank of Scotland  investors has accepted an out-of-court deal to settle a lawsuit that aimed to call disgraced former CEO Fred Goodwin to account over a 12 billion pound ($15 billion) cash call in 2008.

column4: Technology dispute interrupts Statoil's Arctic drilling campaign
column5: OSLO Statoil has interrupted drilling in the Barents Sea in the Arctic region after a court issued a temporary injunction in a technology dispute with a small Norwegian firm  a Statoil spokesman said on Monday.
